Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors
 
 
Sri Lanka 
Project Number: 31624 
January 2014 
   
 
 
Proposed Loan for Additional Financing  
Nepal: Melamchi Water Supply Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public prior to Board consideration in accordance with 
ADB’s Public Communications Policy 2011. Subject to any revisions required following Board 
consideration, this document is deemed final.

(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Nepal for the additional financing of the Melamchi Water Supply Project (MWSP).1 
 
2.  The MWSP supports infrastructure and institutional reforms that are critical to improving 
the Kathmandu Valley’s water supply. The Melamchi tunnel, a key component of the MWSP, is 
critical for supplying bulk water to the Kathmandu Valley,  and its performance affects the 
progress of several other downstream water supply and wastewater projects in the valley. The 
additional financing, which is needed to meet cost overruns resulting from the higher amount of 
the new contract for the Melamchi tunnel, is important to achieve the expected outcomes of the 
MWSP. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) Board of Directors approved the MWSP on 21 
December  2000,  and  the  project  became  effective  on  28  November  2001. 2  It  is  a 
comprehensive water supply project to improve the health and wellbeing of the people in the 
Kathmandu Valley. It aims to alleviate the shortage of potable water in the valley by diverting 
water from the Melamchi River to the Kathmandu Valley.  
 
4.  Since 2004, major events and changing circumstances in Nepal have hampered the 
implementation of the MWSP. The government’s efforts to secure private sector participation to 
manage water services in the Kathmandu Valley were unsuccessful. During the initial years of 
the MWSP, private sector bidders were not interested in a lease contract, supported by the 
World Bank, for water services delivery. When this led to significant delays in project start-up, 
the  World  Bank  canceled  its  funding.  A  subsequent  ADB-supported  performance-based 
management  contract  also failed to  attract  private  sector  interest  despite  several  years  of 
focused efforts. The government and ADB realized that private sector engagement in Nepal’s 
urban water sector was too difficult in the unpredictable sociopolitical environment of that time. 
Consequently,  the  biggest civil  works  package  under the  MWSP—the  27.5 kilometer  (km) 
Melamchi tunnel—was put on hold because the loan covenants included a condition that the 
performance-based  management  contract  had  to  be  awarded  before  the  contract  for  the 
Melamchi tunnel. Furthermore, three development partners withdrew from the MWSP because 
of political developments in that period,3 leaving a funding gap of $133 million equivalent. 
 
5.  The  MWSP  experienced  additional  challenges.  ADB’s  Office  of  the  Special  Project 
Facilitator, and later the Compliance Review Panel, initiated investigations in May 2004 into a 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Nepal for the Melamchi Water Supply Project. Manila. The total project cost was estimated at $464 
million equivalent in 2000 prices, which was to be funded by the Government of Nepal ($118 million) and a 
consortium of development partners: ADB ($120 million), the World Bank ($80 million), the Japan Bank for 
International Cooperation ($52 million), the Japan International Cooperation Agency ($18 million), the Norwegian 
Agency for Development Cooperation ($28 million), the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency 
($25 million), the Nordic Development Fund ($9 million), and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries 
Fund for International Development ($14 million). 
3  World  Bank in  2002,  Norwegian  Agency  for  Development  Cooperation  in 2005,  and  Swedish  International 
Development Cooperation Agency in 2006.

2   
complaint regarding resettlement issues from a nongovernment organization. In June 2005, the 
integrity division of the Office of the Auditor General initiated an investigation into allegations of 
corruption in the procurement process of a contract for the access road.4 Although neither of 
these  investigations  uncovered  any  irregularities,  these  two  cases  delayed  project 
implementation  and  affected  the  decision-making  process  of  the  government  and  the 
implementing agency. 
 
6.  In 2008, ADB approved a major change in the scope and implementation arrangements 
of the loan and associated projects to restructure the project design, optimize the available 
funding, and suit the changed institutional environment.5 The most important change was the 
removal  of  the  loan  covenant  requiring  a  performance-based  management  contract  as  a 
condition for awarding the contract for the Melamchi tunnel. The restructuring of the projects 
allowed construction of the tunnel, which had been on hold from 2000 to 2008, to begin. The 
change in scope did not alter the MWSP’s development benefits or impact. Moreover, the 
MWSP was divided into two subprojects with different implementing agencies, which enhanced 
implementation  efficiency  by  distributing  responsibilities.  The  Melamchi  Water  Supply 
Development Board (MWSDB) continued to implement the Melamchi River water diversion 
subproject (subproject 1), which includes the Melamchi tunnel. The newly established water 
utility Kathmandu Upatyaka Khanepani Limited (KUKL) became the implementing agency for 
the Kathmandu Valley water supply and sanitation subproject (subproject 2), which includes 
distribution network improvements in the valley.  
 
7.  Following the restructuring of the MWSP, the MWSDB awarded the contract for the 
Melamchi tunnel to China Railway 15 Bureau Group Corporation on 19 February 2009 for 
NRs4,288 million. The tunnel was scheduled for completion by 2 September 2013. Physical 
works started in April 2010 because of the time required for preparations, including handing 
over  the  sites  to  the  contractor  and  addressing  social  problems  encountered  in  contract 
implementation. The MWSDB terminated the contract on 25 September 2012 because of the 
unsatisfactory performance of the contractor. As of the termination date, only 23% of tunnel 
excavation—6.3 km of 27.5 km—had been completed.   
 
8.  The MWSDB rebid the tunnel contract, which was awarded to Cooperativa Muratori e 
Cementisti di Ravenna of Italy on 15 July 2013 for NRs8,727 million. The new contract is 
scheduled for completion on 30 September 2016. Additional financing of $25 million from ADB’s 
Special  Funds  resources,  which  is  proposed  to  meet  this  cost  overrun,  will  support  the 
completion of the Melamchi tunnel and the achievement of the original project’s outcomes. The 
proposed additional financing will not change the scope of the restructured project. 
 
9.  While the MWSP is not performing well, both the original and the restructured projects 
remain the most critical components of the water supply system in the Kathmandu Valley. As 
the Melamchi tunnel is essential to achieving the full benefits of an improved water supply 
                                                
4  The Royal Commission for Corruption Control, formed after the royal takeover of 1 February 2005, led the 
investigation. As a result of the commission’s investigation, several high-level government officials—both politicians 
and bureaucrats, including the executive director of the MWSP implementing agency—were imprisoned. This was 
followed by substantial changes in the implementing agency’s top management. After the abolishment of the 
commission following the end of the royal regime, all charges were dropped. 
5  ADB. 2000. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
Kingdom of Nepal for the Melamchi Water Supply Project. Manila; ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Water Services Sector 
Development  Program.  Manila;  ADB.  2008.  Major  Change  in  Scope  and  Implementation  Arrangements: 
Kathmandu Valley Water Services Sector Development Program Manila.

3 
system in the Kathmandu Valley, a reduction in scope or cancellation of the project would not be 
appropriate. A reduction or cancellation of the project at this stage (i) would result in a waste of 
project expenditures, (ii) would be detrimental to the achievement of the government’s sector 
priorities, and (iii) could cause potential reputational risk for ADB. The project continues to be 
technically  feasible  and  economically  sound,  and  the  net  benefits  of  providing  additional 
financing to complete the project far outweigh any other option. 
 
10.  Despite the difficulties, the government has consistently maintained its commitment to 
the  MWSP.  In  addition  to  continuing  infrastructure  development  under  the  MWSP,  the 
government  has  slowly  initiated  institutional  reforms.  The  most  important  reforms  include 
separation of asset ownership from management; establishment of an independent commission 
for regulating water tariffs; and establishment of an autonomous water operator company under 
the Companies Act (1996). Three key entities have been established: (i) the Kathmandu Valley 
Water Supply Management Board, asset owner of water and wastewater systems within the 
valley; (ii) the Water Supply Tariff Fixation Commission, which is responsible for the economic 
regulation of the sector; and (iii) the KUKL, which is in charge of operating the assets under 
lease and license from Kathmandu Valley Water Supply Management Board. Laws have been 
amended or enacted to allow the implementation of these institutional reforms and the private 
sector participation scheme.6 This level of institutional reform in the urban water sector has few 
parallels in South Asia. Moreover, the government and ADB are implementing downstream 
improvement in the water supply distribution network and wastewater management projects in 
the Kathmandu Valley to improve the delivery of water supply and wastewater services.7 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The aggregate impact and outcome of the project as a result of the additional financing 
remain the same as those of the current project. The impact will be the improved health and 
well-being of the people of the Kathmandu Valley. The outcome will be the alleviation of the 
shortage of potable water in the valley. The performance targets and indicators for the impact 
have been revised to reflect the sector-specific impact and are in the design and monitoring 
framework (Appendix 1).  
 
C.  Outputs 
12.  The additional financing will be provided for the Melamchi Valley Subproject (subproject 
1). The aggregate outputs of the MWSP’s two subprojects as a result of the additional financing 
will broadly remain the same as those of the current project. The minor corrections, mainly 
editorial, are in the design and monitoring framework.  
 
13.  The subproject 1 outputs will be as follows: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Raw water diverted from Melamchi Valley to Kathmandu Valley. 
This output will include (a) a 27.5 km Melamchi diversion tunnel completed and 
170 million liters per day (MLD) of bulk water provided to Kathmandu Valley, (b) 
                                                
6  The Water Supply Management Board Act (Act No. 21, 2063 [2006]). The Water Supply Tariff Fixation Commission 
Act (Act No. 29, 2063). The Nepal Water Supply Corporation (Third Amendment) Act (2063). 
7  ADB. 2011. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Nepal for 
the Kathmandu Valley Water Supply Improvement Project. Manila; ADB. 2013. Report and Recommendation of the 
President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Wastewater Management 
Project. Manila.

4   
25 km of new access roads and upgrading of 29 km of access roads completed, 
and (c) water treatment plant with potential capacity of 170 MLD completed with 
Japan International Cooperation Agency assistance and treating raw water from 
Melamchi Valley. 
(ii)  Output 2: Social and environmental support provided in Melamchi Valley. 
This  output  will  include  (a)  Social  development  support  (including  income 
generation),  buffer  zone  development,  and  a  health  and  education  program 
implemented and benefiting inhabitants; and (b) resettlement action plan, public 
relations plan, and environmental management plan implemented through the 
Melamchi  Valley  Development  Committee,  and  potential  negative  impact  on 
affected people mitigated. 
(iii)  Output 3: Efficient project management established and capacity building 
attained. This output will include a project management unit (PMU) established 
with  effective  decision-making  mechanisms,  as  well  as  a  market-driven 
performance management system, remuneration system, and standard operating 
procedures in place.  
 
14.  The subproject 2 outputs will be same as those for the current project: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Institutional reforms achieved and efficiently operated. This output 
will include (a) performance targets under lease and license agreement achieved, 
(b) water tariff adjusted in accordance with cost recovery principles, and (c) water 
levy paid from Kathmandu Valley inhabitants to Melamchi Valley inhabitants. 
(ii)  Output 2: Water distribution and wastewater system improved. This output 
will include (a) capital works for bulk distribution system and distribution network 
improvement  undertaken  and  potable  water  supplied  8  hours  per  day,  (b) 
additional  raw  water  source  provides  15  MLD,  and  (c)  wastewater  facilities 
rehabilitated. 
(iii)  Output 3: Social and environmental support provided in Kathmandu Valley. 
This output will include hygiene education and promotion program, support to a 
low-income  customer  support  unit,  and  environmental  management  plan 
materialized. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
15.  The project is estimated to cost $355.4 million with additional financing of $38.1 million 
(Table 1). Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category are in the project administration 
manual.8 
                                                
8  Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

5

f
  Of the original $317.32 million, as of 30 June 2013, $166 million had been disbursed, including $64.26 million by 
ADB. Undisbursed funds from the original committed amounts are $72.74 million for ADB, $2.54 million for the 
Nordic Development Fund, and $4.35 million for the Japan International Cooperation Agency. 
Source: ADB estimates.  
 
16.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
SDR16,215,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the additional financing for 
the MWSP. The loan will have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest 
rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other 
terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements.  The  government 
continues to avail of the ongoing loans from other development partners such as the Japan 
Bank for International Cooperation, the Japan International Cooperation Agency, the Nordic 
Development  Fund,  and  the  Organization  of  Petroleum  Exporting  Countries  Fund  for 
International  Development.  The  additional  financing  loan  will  be  utilized  once  the  amount 
allocated for the civil works under the original loan is fully committed and utilized. Interest during 
construction for the ADB loan will be funded entirely by ADB.9 
 
17.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  funds  of  $13.08  million,  or  34.3%  of  the 
additional financing cost, to finance taxes and duties and part of the civil works and project 
implementation support. The government will provide the loan proceeds and counterpart funds 
to the MWSDB as a grant. The government has assured ADB that it is fully committed to 
completing this project, and would provide extra financial resources from its own funds, if 
required,  without  requesting  any  further  financial  support  from  ADB  for  this  project.  The 
government will also provide for the contingent liability for the bonus for early completion, which 
is  in  the  new  contract  for  the  Melamchi  tunnel.  The  government  will  assume  the  foreign 
exchange risk. The updated financing plan is in Table 2. 
 
                                                
9 In addition, ADB may finance local transportation and insurance costs.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the  project  administration  manual  (footnote  8).  The  only  change  in  the  implementation 
arrangements of the MWSP is the closing date, which has been extended from 31 December 
2013 to 31 December 2016 in line with that for the additional financing loan. The procurement of 
works, goods, and services financed by ADB will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2013,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Consultant  selection  and 
engagement will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time).

7 
19.  The Nordic Development Fund is financing the design and construction supervision 
consultant for the MWSP. The government will assess the additional cost of the consultant up to 
the revised closing date. The funds available under the original loan may be used to supplement 
the government funds to meet the additional requirement of the consultant to ensure continuous 
construction supervision until the revised closing date. The government has also requested to 
increase the percentage of ADB financing of the civil works under the original loan. The original 
loan categories have been amended to reflect the revised requirements. 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
20.  Rebidding  process  and  the  new  contract.  After  the  termination  of  the  previous 
contract  for  the  Melamchi  tunnel  in  September  2012,  the  MWSDB  revised  the  detailed 
engineering  design  and  bidding  documents,  work  methodology,  equipment,  materials 
requirements, and cost estimates. Advance procurement for the new tunnel contract and the 
ongoing  tunnel  supervision  consultants  will  ensure  high  project  readiness.  The  MWSDB’s 
capacity has been strengthened through the deputation of additional qualified technical staff 
from the Ministry of Urban Development. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
21.  Economic  analysis.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  the  overall 
project including the additional financing is 18.92%; the net present value is $225.62 million.10 
The economic internal rate of return is higher than the economic opportunity cost of capital of 
12%, indicating a sufficient economic return. The results from a sensitivity analysis, which range 
from 17.47% to 18.92%, are satisfactory against downside risks, including a 10% increase in 
capital expenditure, a 10% increase in operating costs, a 10% decrease in benefits, and a 1-
year delay in project completion.  
 
22.  Financial analysis. The estimated financial internal rate of return of the overall project 
including the additional financing is 7.93%; the net present value is $1.6 million.11 The financial 
internal rate of return is slightly higher than the weighted average cost of capital, estimated at 
7.90%, indicating an adequate financial return. The sensitivity analysis reveals that financial 
viability of the project is most vulnerable to decreases in revenues, and efforts will be made by 
KUKL  to  rationalize  tariffs  and  enhance revenues. The future  profitability  of  KUKL  will  be 
evaluated  once  the  water  utility  provides  accurate  financial  projections,  which  are  a 
disbursement condition for the Kathmandu Valley Wastewater Management Project (footnote 7). 
Tariff levels were increased in July 2013 by more than 80% and are expected to increase further 
when water becomes available from the Melamchi tunnel. The government also agreed in July 
2013 to shoulder KUKL’s tax burden through a grant to the utility. With support from the ongoing 
loans  (footnotes  5  and  7),  KUKL  will  continually  work  to  make  operational  and  financial 
improvements, including significant reductions in nonrevenue water. These elements are likely 
to improve financial performance soon after the completion of the MWSP.  
 
                                                
10 Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
11 Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8   
C.  Governance 
23.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  MWSDB.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 8). Based on these 
assessments, some of the mitigation measures incorporated in the project design aim to (i) 
establish a mechanism for regular voluntary disclosure of project-related information to citizens; 
(ii) regularly update the project website to enhance transparency in project implementation, 
procurement, and safeguards; and (iii) establish a grievance redress mechanism to ensure 
quick and effective resolution. The financial management assessment of the MWSDB, which 
has been updated since 2008, does not indicate that any additional risks or mitigating measures 
will  be  required.12 Detailed  accounting  and  auditing  arrangements  are given  in  the  project 
administration manual. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
24.  A poverty and social analysis has been completed, and the additional financing project is 
classified as no gender elements.13 While the additional financing has limited impact on the 
social and gender aspects of the people in the Kathmandu Valley, the downstream water supply 
and wastewater projects (footnote 7) prioritize connecting all poor households and households 
headed by women to the water supply and sewerage network in the Kathmandu Valley. Under 
these projects, the government and KUKL have committed to reform current water supply and 
sewerage connection policies to facilitate individual connections to the poor, socially excluded, 
and households headed by women. Connection fees will be reduced for poor households under 
these projects. A social uplift program (SUP) under the MWSP is being implemented to promote 
widespread, ongoing, and meaningful participation of key stakeholders. 14 These projects will 
complement KUKL's ongoing efforts to strengthen its pro-poor and gender-inclusive sanitation 
services.   
 
E.  Safeguards 
25.  Social safeguards. The additional financing is classified category C for both involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009).15 The additional financing for the MWSP will not change the safeguards requirements 
from the original project as there will be no additional scope or civil works to be implemented. 
The PMU submits regular social safeguard monitoring reports to ADB, and these are reviewed 
and disclosed in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). No significant 
social safeguard implementation issues have arisen, and the PMU is capable of effectively 
implementing all safeguards. SUP activities will be continued for Melamchi Valley in line with the 
original scope and will cover five areas: buffer zone development, health, education, income 
generation, and community development. The inputs of the safeguard and social development 
support consultant will be continued to (i) build capacity of the Melamchi Valley Development 
Committee, MWSDB, and relevant stakeholders; (ii) support the development committee in 
                                                
12 Draft Financial Management Assessment: Melamchi Water Supply Development Board (accessible from the list of 
supplementary linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13  Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
14 The SUP is a program under the MWSP’s social and environmental support component to mitigate direct and 
indirect  project  impacts  and  improve  the living conditions of  the local  population  in  project-affected  village 
development committees.  
15 The original project was classified category A for involuntary resettlement and category C for indigenous peoples.

9 
implementing SUP activities and create community ownership; and (iii) ensure the subproject is 
implemented in accordance with social and environmental safeguard requirements, and monitor 
safeguard compliance. 
 
26.  Environmental safeguards. The additional financing is classified category C for the 
environment.16  An environmental management plan was prepared and disclosed in accordance 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The PMU submits regular environmental safeguard 
monitoring reports to ADB, and these are reviewed and disclosed in accordance with ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. No significant environmental safeguard implementation issues has 
arisen, and the PMU is capable of effectively implementing all safeguards. Appropriate clauses 
are incorporated in the tunnel contract to control the adverse impacts of construction. This is 
expected  to  mitigate  environmental  impacts  such  as  (i)  damage  to  the  water  quality  of 
waterways, (ii) increased erosion, (iii) deterioration of air quality at the construction site, (iv) loud 
sounds from blasting or machines, and (v) failure to rehabilitate land temporarily occupied by 
the contractor. The tunnel supervision consultant is responsible for ensuring that contractors 
follow contract specifications, particularly for environmental mitigation. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
27.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.17 The integrated benefits and impacts of the 
additional financing are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Cost  and  time  overruns  caused  by  poor  The engineer will closely monitor mobilization and 
mobilization of the contractor or procedural delays  performance  of  the  contractor  for  the  Melamchi 
tunnel to ensure that progress stays on schedule, 
and  will  take  action  according  to  contractual 
provisions for any delay. Provisions for bonus for 
early completion and penalties for the delays, as 
incorporated  in  the  bidding  documents,  will  be 
enforced.  The  MWSDB  will  prepare  timelines  for 
decisions for handing over the sites and approving 
designs,  drawings,  variations,  claims,  and  other 
contractual  matters;  and  will  strictly  monitor 
compliance with the timelines. The MOUD and ADB 
will also regularly monitor the progress, quality, and 
compliance with safeguards. The DSC will support 
project  management,  safeguards,  reporting,  and 
training on FIDIC contracts. ADB will field frequent 
missions to oversee project performance. 
Loss of life and property because of uncertain  The MWSDB and the engineer will ensure that the 
geological  conditions  and  hazardous  site  contractor takes adequate safety measures. Tunnel 
conditions  excavation will be permitted only after ascertaining 
the geological conditions using a probe drill, geo-
radar,  and  other  suitable  techniques.  Because 
tunnel  construction  is  inherently  hazardous,  the 
contractor will be required to enforce the highest 
                                                
16 The original project was classified category A for environmental safeguards. 
17 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10   
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
standards  of  safety  for  works,  workers,  and 
residents at the work sites. An emergency response 
and disaster mitigation plan will be prepared and 
strictly enforced to minimize the risks to life and 
property.  
Local communities oppose the construction of the  The  MWSDB,  with  the  support  of  the  DSC  and 
Melamchi tunnel  SSDS consultants, will raise awareness and inform 
all stakeholders, including political parties, about the 
critical nature of the Melamchi tunnel in order to 
generate  a  consensus  for  successful 
implementation. SUP activities will be implemented 
in the Melamchi Valley to address the basic needs 
of the project-affected villages. A grievance redress 
mechanism will be established to receive, evaluate, 
and  facilitate  the  resolution  of  local  communities’ 
concerns, complaints, and grievances.  
Delays  in  payments  to  contractors  and   Standard operating procedures (time of payment, 
consultants  responsibility, and interest on delayed payment) will 
be agreed upon to expedite the processing of claims 
by contractors and consultants. The MWSDB has 
agreed that payments to contractors and consultants 
will be by ADB’s direct payment method. ADB will 
monitor  payments  to  the  contractors  and 
consultants. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DSC = design, supervision, and management consultant, FIDIC = Fédération 
Internationale Des Ingénieurs-Conseils (International Federation of Consulting Engineers); MOUD = Ministry of Urban 
Development, MWSDB = Melamchi Water Supply Development Board, SSDS = safeguards and social development 
support, SUP = social uplift program.  
Source: Asian Development Bank.  
 
IV.  ASSURANCES  
28.  The government and the MOUD have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
29.  The government and the MOUD have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan agreement.     
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
30.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR16,215,000 to Nepal for the additional financing of the Melamchi 
Water Supply Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate 
of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 
years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board. 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
17 January 2014

metadata.Subject: This is the report and recommendation of the president (RRP) on a proposed loan to Nepal for the additional financing of the Melamchi Water Supply Project.
metadata.Title: RRP: Nepal: Melamchi Water Supply Project - Additional Financing

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 20 December 2013) 
 
Currency unit  –  Nepalese rupee/s (NRe/NRs) 
NRe1.00  =  $ 0.01012   
$1.00  =  NRs98.751    
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
km  –  kilometer 
KUKL  –  Kathmandu Upatyaka Khanepani Limited 
MOUD  –  Ministry of Urban Development 
MWSDP  –  Melamchi Water Supply Development Board 
MLD  –  million liters per day 
MWSP  –  Melamchi Water Supply Project 
PMU  –  project management unit  
SUP  –  social uplift program 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Nepal and its agencies ends on 15 
July. FY before a calendar year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, 
e.g., FY2013 ends on 15 July 2013.  
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
Vice-President  W. Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  F. Yue, Urban Development and Water Division, SARD 
   
Team leaders  M. Sharma, Senior Urban Development Specialist, SARD 
  L. Sharma, Senior Project Officer (Infrastructure), Nepal Resident Mission, 
SARD 
Team members  V. Castro, Urban Development Specialist, SARD 
A. Cervantes, Operations Assistant, SARD 
J. Ghimire, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
E. Moises, Senior Operations Assistant, SARD 
  E. Ravancho, Operations Assistant, SARD 
S. Shafiq, Financial Management Specialist, SARD 
  R. Slangen, Urban Development Specialist, SARD 
Peer reviewer  A. Baird, Senior Water Supply and Sanitation Specialist, Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department  
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
